title: Darts news: Gerwyn Price sends message to fans after painful World Grand Prix exit
text:
Gerwyn Price suffered an early exit at the World Grand Prix (Picture: Getty Images)

Gerwyn Price has sent a heartfelt thank you message to his supporters after enduring abuse from the crowd during a painful first round exit from the World Grand Prix.

The Iceman was beaten 2-1 by Dave Chisnall in the last 32 in Dublin, playing well below his brilliant best and ending with an average of 79.69 in the double-in event.

The contest saw Price booed and jeered throughout, something that has become customary for the Welshman to deal with over the last year.

The 34-year-old’s vociferous celebrations and sometime aggressive nature on stage has led to him becoming something of a pantomime villain for darts fans.

This largely stemmed from the controversial Grand Slam of Darts final last year, in which Price beat Gary Anderson to lift the trophy, but was fined for gamesmanship and bringing the game into disrepute for his actions during the match.

The abuse from the crowd may have become commonplace, but it still has an impact on the Welshman, who took to Instagram after defeat to Chisnall, writing: ‘I hope U all get joy making someone look and feel like s**t’

The post clearly rallied Price’s fans into action as he wrote on Instagram on Tuesday night: ‘Honestly overwhelmed with the messages the last 24hrs or so really means the world and makes me more determined to go out and do it not just for myself and friends but also for everyone that genuinely supports me through thick and thin. #love you all’

Controversy follows the Iceman around the PDC tour, after he was involved in spats with both James Wade and Daryl Gurney during this year’s Premier League.

There were also contentious moments as recently as 4 October this year when Price beat Krzysztof Ratajski in the final of Players Championship 27.

The Grand Slam champion punched a table and refused a fist bump from the Pole ahead of the deciding leg, before going on to win 8-7.

‘We don’t meet eye to eye, he plays his game I play mine. I’m not going to fist bump him to wish him all the best in the last leg – I hope he plays rubbish!’ Price said after the victory.

Gerwyn Price refusing Krzysztof Ratajski's offer of a fist bump in that heated final on Friday. Afterwards he said: "We don't meet eye to eye, he plays his game I play mine. I'm not going to fist bump him to wish him all the best in the last leg – I hope he plays rubbish!" pic.twitter.com/lLnBrs6y14 — Chris Hammer (@ChrisHammer180) October 5, 2019

Metro.co.uk spoke to Price back in February about his behaviour on stage, with the world number six saying: ‘I don’t go up on stage to try and prove people wrong, I just go up there to try and be myself. If I win I win, if I lose I lose, I don’t let the good or bad comments get to me, I do my own thing.’
